Without going into a great amount of excessive detail, US produced goods can never be produced at a cost even close to being competitive with goods imported from developing industrial nations, using China as an example, regardless of any tax structure. That will change after the US reaches a point of financial restructuring, but that's years away. 
 
 There are two financial considerations that are called cost of goods sold and operating overhead. Cost of goods sold is subtracted from the product sale price to establish what's called gross profit margin. Operating overhead is then subtracted from gross profit to determine net profit. There are no taxes involved to this point. Taxes are below the line (net profit line) deductions. 
 
 Cost of goods sold includes the actual labor, benefits and materials required to produce a product. Chinese labor, all skill levels averaged, is about 10% of that in the US. Materials in China, because China operates on a positive trade balance, are less expensive than the US because they pay no financing costs. Until the US adjusts our standard of living to where employees are seeking minimum wage jobs with socialized benefits, another 7-8% savings on 941 taxes isn't going to change anything. 
 
 Operating overhead is fixed, and includes management salaries, plant costs, compliance costs and all other costs not associated with actual production of the product. I don't have a comparison number of US to Chinese overheads, but considering US management/administration salaries, benefits, land costs, building costs and OSHA/etc compliance costs, I doubt that they'd even come close to 30% of US overheads. 
 
 Those factors will not change regardless of any US or Chinese tax structures until the US standard of living takes a dump or the Chinese raise theirs. Don't hold your breath, Chinese long-range plans include a target date of 2020 for a $10,000 (US) per capita income. Anybody care to guess at ours?
